trial_identification.studytitle: Is bedside ultrasound a valuable tool for diagnosing common fractures in emergency department patients?
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Is bedside ultrasound a valuable tool for diagnosing common fractures in emergency department patients?

interventions.interventions: Prospective convenience sampling of patients with suspected fracture of selected regions. Perform bedside ultrasonography using portable SONOSITE MicroMaxx ultrasound machine using a 12MHz transducer. Patients will be observed for 6 months.
interventions.comparator: Comparing to diagnosis made from Xray/Computerised Tomography scan (CT)/Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI).

primaryOutcome.outcome: Sensitivity of using ultrasound to diagnose fractures.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: At completion of ultrasound scan and/or Xray/CT/MRI whichever is later.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Specificity of using ultrasound to diagnose fractures.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: At completion of ultrasound scan and/or Xray/CT/MRI whichever is later.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: To determine if time to correct diagnosis of the presence or absence of fracture can be reduced by the use of Ultrasound
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At completion of ultrasound scan and/or Xray/CT/MRI whichever is later.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Patient with suspected fractures involving the metacarpal, distal radius/ulnar, olecranon, body of ulnar, clavicle, metatarsal, distal tibia/fibula, patella, proximal fibula, mandible or sternum.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Patient unable to give own consent Patients with unstable, compound (open) or suspected open fractures Haemodynamically unstable patients requiring urgent medical intervention Patients with fracture dislocations requiring immediate relocation to avoid neurovascular compromisation Enrolling clinician has already reviewed Xrays and made diagnosis prior performing ultrasound for the study

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Department of Emergency Medicine Royal Adelaide Hospital North Terrace Adelaide SA 5000

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The primary purpose of this study is to determine if using a bedside ultrasound machine is as good as using an Xray to determine if a bone is fractured. A positive outcome from this study may speed up the treatment of patients with similar injuries and avoid unecessary exposure to radiation.

ethicscommitee.ethicaddress: Royal Adelaide Hospital North Terrace Adelaide SA 5000
